div.head: Seaside Resorts
div.p: In June 1819, Margaret Ruskin wrote to John James when he was at Weymouth, recommending that he “try cautiously the sea”: “take but one plunge come out instantly rub yourself perfectly dry and if you should feel no cold nor headake try it again at the interval of the day.” If this experiment made him “sensible of benefit,” she urged him to “stay [at] the seaside as long as business will permit” in order to strengthen his health (Ruskin Family Letters, 95). Apparently, the trial convinced the couple of the salubriousness of sea bathing, as in 1822 Margaret referred pleasantly to Sandgate (a journey that must have occurred in the interval, in the summer of 1820 or 1821, and that in 1822 already represented to John at age three the standard for outdoor pleasure); and Ruskinʼs earliest sustained narrative, “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1, recounts a visit to Hastings (see Ruskin Family Letters, 107, 108; and see also Tours of 1822–25 and Tours of 1826–27).

Weymouth ranked among the most splendid early seaside destinations, having served as the resort for George III, who acquired from his brother, Duke of Gloucester, a residence on the Esplanade. For family holidays, the Ruskins, however, appear to have been drawn to less grand (and less expensive?) resorts closer to London, Hastings and Sandgate. . . . [more on early Victorian sea bathing]

In 1823, at the same time that the Ruskins showed so much delight in their seaside visits, William Cobbett, while admiring the beauty of Sandgate and Folkstone, was struck mainly by the areaʼs Mortello towers, defensive works that had been erected to guard against Napoleonic invasion. Cobbett railed against the costliness of “these ridiculous things,” thirty of which he counted stretching in a “chain” from Sandgate “all the way to Hastings!” For him, they represented the governmentʼs extravagance that was “sending some farmers to the workhouse and driving others to flee the country or to cut their throats!” (Cobbett, Rural Rides, September 3, 1). The Ruskins are likely to have gazed on these structures with opposite feelings of patriotism.

div.head: Hastings
div.p: A town and port on the shore (or rape) of Sussex. In the 1820's, the distance from London was 64 miles. [Pick up on tourism, Moss 123, 145-46]

The vicinity was best known as the historical site of the Battle of Hastings, which, in the language of an 1824 history of the town, “changed the destinies . . . of the nation, by annihilating the Saxon dynasty, and substituting that of the Norman in its stead” (Moss, Hastings 1). When the Ruskins visited in 1826, attractions would have included the castle ruins, of which survived “a few fragments . . . , presenting grotesque and fantastic forms, from different points in which they may be viewed. The only remains now [in 1824] in any degree perfect, are small portions of a round and square Tower, with a part of the sally-port. Its site is on a rocky cliff on the westward of the Town” (Moss, Hastings 60).

Of ecclesiastical ruins, “gloomy but interesting vestiges of monastic grandeur remain[ed] . . . heighten[ing] the picturesque beauties of the local scenery.” The most prominent churches were All Saints, believed to stand “in its original state” from the early fourteenth century; and St. Clements, parts of which also dated to the fourteenth century (Moss, Hastings 78, 97, 112).
[Pick up on views, Moss 123-24, 126] . There was also a view of the town from the site of a Roman encampment, on the hill east of the town.

On the shore, there was a fort and a landing place (stade or staithe), where Ruskin was probably diverted by observing the bustle of related to shipping, fishing, and boat‐building, such as watching vessels launched—perhaps the model for Harryʼs experiments with his toy boat, or for the drawing “Harry Seeing a Ship Launch,” [Plate] “6,” [“Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1] (See “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1, ).
